key_points: The ISIS-K suicide bomber responsible for the Kabul airport attack in late August, killing 13 US service members and dozens of Afghans, was released from Parwan prison near Kabul days before the attack.
The Taliban took control of the area and released several prisoners, including members of ISIS-K, when they seized Parwan prison at Bagram air base and Pul-e-Charkhi prison near Kabul.
The attack highlighted the chaotic final days of the US withdrawal from Afghanistan and the struggle to secure Kabul airport's perimeter.
Two US officials and Rep. Ken Calvert confirmed the identity of the suicide bomber as Abdul Rehman Al-Loghri.
Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen. Mark Milley warned of the potential reconstitution of al Qaeda or ISIS-K within 6 to 36 months.
Rep. Ken Calvert criticized the handling of the withdrawal, linking it to the events leading to the airport attack.
The Biden administration was criticized for how it abandoned Bagram air base, a crucial military complex, and its coordination with Afghan authorities.
Officials estimated 5,000 prisoners at Bagram at the time of handover, the majority identified as terrorists.
The rapid fall of Afghan districts and eventual control of Kabul by the Taliban was accelerated by the US withdrawal.
Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin defended the decision to leave Bagram, emphasizing the focus on protecting the US embassy.
